sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to this special edition on Euronews brought to you from Lviv in western Ukraine with me Anneliese Borges.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It's Thursday the 24th of March and it's been one month since Russia invaded this country, sparking the biggest crisis Europe has seen in generations. Let's take a look now at where the conflict stands right now. Russian troops control large swathes of territory in the east of Ukraine with the support of separatist rebels there. They have also taken a large corridor in the south of the country by the Sea of Azov, almost completely encircling the port city of Mariupol. Around the capital, fighting continues, but Russian troops have failed to surround the city. Ukrainian soldiers are said to be holding positions there and even repelling some of Russia's offensives, like, for example, in the city of Makariv, to the west of Kiev. From the capital, President Volodymyr Zelensky has been addressing the world and calling for demonstrations in support of his country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: He has also addressed Russian President Vladimir Putin, pleading for direct talks, something that the Kremlin has so far rejected.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And while diplomatic efforts fail to yield results, the toll of this war continues to climb.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Tens of thousands of people are thought to have been killed and 10 million Ukrainians have been displaced by the fighting. Let's take a look now at how it all started exactly one month ago. Sirens rumbling and plumes of smoke on the horizon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The unthinkable becomes materialized. War has broken out and tens of thousands of Russian soldiers invade Ukraine from the north, east and south.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: In a few hours, they seize Chernobyl power plant. President Zelensky orders a general mobilization of all males aged over 18.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: In the following days, the West announces an unprecedented cascade of sanctions against Russia, disconnecting it from the international financial system.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Putin puts his nuclear deterrent forces on high alert.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian resistance is fierce and unexpected.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Zelensky refuses to be evacuated and multiplies his patriotic messages through social networks and his passionate requests for help to the international community are watched by millions around the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Russian troops advance to the east and in the south where they take control of Kherson, the first major city to fall into Russian hands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Leaving behind catastrophic scenes, millions of Ukrainians are forced to evacuate to neighboring countries,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: the overwhelming majority of them women and children.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Most head over to Poland in a perilous journey.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But the invasion is barely underway and the frustration of the Russian army is seen from space.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Satellite images show the blockade of gigantic military convoys on the highway leading to Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The spectre of Chechen or Syrian-style war appears on the horizon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Moscow undertakes massive bombings without regard for civilian casualties and a merciless siege of Mariupol on the Sea of Azov.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: A maternity and child hospital is bombed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: A week later, bombs destroy a theatre converted into a shelter with hundreds of civilians inside.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Most attempts to open humanitarian corridors fail in Mariupol, which has begun burying victims in mass graves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Turned into a pariah on the international scene, the Russian president mingled with the crowd in Moscow on the eighth anniversary of the annexation of Crimea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: A month has passed and the war continues. There are thousands of dead on both sides and many of them are ukrainian civilians the number of refugees has passed three and a half million people a further six and a half million internally displaced persons and the dialogue of the death continues when it comes to stopping the fighting katie dartford euronews multiple diplomatic efforts have been undertaken to try and bring the fighting to a halt, but so far this is a war with no end in sight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Earlier this week, the UN Secretary-General, Antonio Guterres, has called on Moscow to stop its, quote, absurd war, describing this conflict as unwinnable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Continuing the war in Ukraine is morally unacceptable, politically indefensible, and militarily nonsensical.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: What I said from this podium almost one month ago should be even more evident today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: By any measure, by even the shrewdest calculation, it is time to stop the fighting now and give peace a chance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Four weeks of fighting have sparked a humanitarian crisis of unprecedented proportions in this country's recent history. Earlier, I spoke to Ukraine's Minister for Territorial Development, currently in charge of humanitarian aid here in this country, and asked him about the conditions in some of the areas the hardest hit by the conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: Mariupol is in a terrible situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: We have the reports of 1.5 thousand buildings completely destroyed in Mariupol. We have no possibility to bring any food and water to this city. The city is almost wiped off from the earth in the region of Donetsk. And that is not the only city like this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: We have a daily bombing in the second largest city, which is called Kharkiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: And we are witnessing more than 800 damaged and destroyed multi-level and multi-apartment buildings. And this is, of course, a catastrophe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_17
sentences.sentence: During our interview, the shelling and bombing continues, and the people are dying in several Ukrainian cities, and the number of them is going higher and higher so uh if we are speaking about the damages we might consider the instruct including a road including residential and non-residential buildings and including even power plants which are at this moment not nuclear and i hope it will not go up to that end.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: On the 24th of February, Vladimir Putin launched a full-fledged invasion of Ukraine, the biggest such military operation in Europe since World War II. And he recently implied the possibility of nuclear escalation if the West was to intervene.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Can Vladimir Putin be stopped?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And what, if anything, will stop him?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: For this and more, I'm now joined by Euronews correspondent Galina Polonskaya.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Galina, military strategists and analysts said that this was going to be fast and easy, that Russian troops were going to take Kiev in a matter of days. Obviously, this has not happened yet. And many are reporting that Russian troops may be losing steam. Now, U.S. President Joe Biden has said, has warned that Russia could be preparing to adopt an even more dramatic strategy. What is Moscow's next move likely to be well that's a million dollar question of course today the state TV has shown President Putin meeting with the country's Security Council but there was no sound and we do not know what they've discussed Russia says that everything goes according to the initial plan but many uh observers from the west say that russia is thinking about a plan b which could be much more devastating that we have seen so far the u.s president and the nato secretary general have warned that russia could be seeking um pretext to use chemical weapons in Ukraine. And we also know that Russia's nuclear arsenal is on high alert. It was decided by President Putin. Russia also wants NATO to stay away from the country and says that it will hit convoys with military help. So very, very worrying signals and NATO countries are deciding to provide Ukraine with equipment to protect itself from chemical attacks or nuclear threats.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And New York Times wrote that Washington assembled a team of national security officials who are thinking about such scenarios.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And the paper underlines that a month ago such scenarios were just theoretical, and now this is not the case anymore.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The Euronews' Galina Polonskaya, thank you very much for that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Now, for more on what the war has meant for Ukrainians here, I'm now joined by Konstantin Shishkin, who is a tech entrepreneur, normally based in Boston in the United States.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: You were here in a business trip when this war started.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Why did you decide to stay?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Why is it important to be in Ukraine at this moment?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I was a student during the Orange Revolution back in 2004. I was the one beating the drum next to the city council in Odessa. Then when Maidan happened in 2014, I was there in Kiev helping to build the barricades from snow and ice. And now this war has happened. Guess where should I be? So now I'm here in Lviv helping with procurement and supply of different things.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And let me leave it at that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And why? Because entrepreneurs, you know, we're about making impact, changing the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And perhaps this is my best ever opportunity to do so.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So if not now, then when? And even if it would be my last one.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: You said that you were procuring help. How is the international community faring so far in helping your country?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, first, let me say thank you to the world and to the European community for everything what you've done for our refugees, for sending weapons, for setting up all these relief funds and support packages.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Otherwise, we run the risk of just complaining about everything, and it shouldn't be this way.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: To answer your question, I think we need more weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So tactically, let me echo our leadership, because they know what they're talking about.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The time of guerrilla war of small anti-tank missiles has passed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: If you want us to attack, to counterattack and to kick them out, we need bigger weapons right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We need this fast.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And then strategically, what else you can do?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So you've placed so many sanctions on Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Please keep putting pressure.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This is working.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And I think strategically your next battle in Europe there would be on energy front.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Everyone is saying that you will consider energy rationing in 2023.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Why not now? Think about it sooner.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Because this helps. And the other decisions of putting pressure on businesses are also helping this situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So is that your message to the world right now about your country, about Ukraine? Let me share my experience as a volunteer, because this is what we do here every day. Small things matter. Do little every day. Don't spend all your money in single donation, but maybe spread it a little bit and give it to small volunteer groups. Don't give everything to the big funds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Fight on the information front.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Help tackling misinformation and also speaking to people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Help your food company to make the right choice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: You know which one I'm talking about.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I know it's tough, but this is what you can do all together.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And we can suffocate them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And we need the common effort effort and we need it fast.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Konstantin Shishkin, founder of Spiral Technology, thank you very much for joining us here on Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: One month on and the way out of this conflict is very difficult to foresee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ukraine and Russia had signaled they were nearing an agreement earlier this month, but talks continue dragging on and the human cost of this conflict continues to climb do stay with Euronews for all the latest in our continued coverage of the war in Ukraine for now from our team here in Lviv thank you for watching diplomatic talks are intensifying in Brussels as NATO G7 and EU leaders meet to discuss the ongoing conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg, whose term has just been extended, says the war has changed Europe's security environment for the foreseeable future.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For now, it also appears to have brought Western nations together in their effort to stop Russia's military assault.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Christopher Pitchess sent this report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: US President Joe Biden is in Europe to push allies to take tougher measures fault. Christopher Pitchess sent this report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: U.S. President Joe Biden is in Europe to push allies to take tougher measures against Vladimir Putin's Russia. First stop, NATO's headquarters in Brussels, where leaders are once again asking the Kremlin to put an end to the invasion. NATO allies have already agreed to deploy four new battlegroups to Europe's eastern flank and also to send Ukraine supplies to face any possible chemical or biological attack from Moscow. for å forplasse fire nye krigsgrupper til Europas østflank, og også for å sende Ukrains oppslipp til å oppføre hvilke kjemikal eller biologiske attacker fra Moskva. law and it will have widespread consequences and of course be extremely dangerous it will affect the people in ukraine but there's also a risk that will have a direct effect on people living in nato countries during the meeting ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky addressed NATO leaders via video link, with a very precise list of demands, to send 1 percent of NATO planes and tanks to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He also accused Moscow of using phosphorus bombs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: VOLODYMYR ZELENSKY, Ukrainian President- It's not your missiles. It's not your bombs that are destroying our cities. This morning, by the way, there were phosphorus bombs, phosphorus Russian bombs. Adults were killed again and children were killed again. are destroying our cities. This morning, by the way, there were phosphorus bombs, phosphorus Russian bombs. Adults were killed again and children were killed again. I just want you to know NATO can still prevent the deaths of Ukrainians from Russian strikes, from Russian occupation by giving us all the weapons we need." NATO is also sending a message to China, asking them to join the rest of the world in condemnation of Russia and refraining from supporting its war efforts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Chris Lepic, Euronews, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For more on this, let's go over to Brussels, once again the center of global diplomacy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And in the thick of it all we find our correspondent shona murray shona great to see you there now as the war in ukraine drags on there are growing fears that putin might resort to weapons of mass destruction how has the nato summit address addressed that issue well that's right i mean we heard from Jens Stoltenberg today. We've heard this over the past few days, essentially, that there's fears that there could be a false flag operation from Russia, given the way the Russians have been talking about the U.S. and Ukraine creating biological and chemical weapons to be used in Ukraine against Russians.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Now, Jens Stoltenberg said that that would change the nature of the conflict and that NATO's top military commander has activated NATO's defences to protect against potential biological chemical warfare. Because, of course, the point being that if Russia were to use that in Ukraine, there would be possibly a contagion effect given the nature of biological and chemical weapons. And, of course course that would require a direct response from NATO if it did enter NATO territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: In addition to this, of course, it would be such a clear breach of international law that NATO would morally have to respond, but he didn't give details as to how that would be, other than to say Vladimir Putin needs to end this saber rattling around nuclear and other sort of deeply harmful weapons in this war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Stefan?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Obviously, you have other countries outside the West, Japan and so on, here for the G7 meeting, all very much supportive of these strong sanctions against Russia as a deterrent for the invasion of Ukraine and the breach of international law that's been subsequent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Part of this is also about trying to get more unity globally, because there are countries that aren't on board with sanctions, like India, like China, countries that may be trying to circumvent sanctions. So it's really about that, too. But I got up with Roberta Mazzola, who's the president of the European Parliament earlier today, and I asked her what she hoped the best can be achieved at today's summit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The most important is unity.

The next steps will have to be that we need to revise how we are going to work in the situation where we have the largest humanitarian crisis since the Second World War.

But what we don know is that whether oil or gas will ever make those sanctions, not in the short term at least.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you very much and keep it up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has been holding talks

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: with the head of the Red Cross about the desperate humanitarian situation in Ukraine.

sentences.sentence: Kyiv says Moscow is guilty of war crimes and has violated ceasefire agreements aimed at protecting civilians.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But the Kremlin insists it's willing to find a solution.

sentences.sentence: Tom Bolton has this report.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The number of people fleeing Ukraine continues to grow, with an estimated 3.5 million said to have escaped.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now the focus is on social media companies to do more to ensure their safety online as they search for new homes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Here's Matthew in the Cube with more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, Stefan, since the war began over a month ago, countries around the world have been stepping up their offers to offer homes to Ukrainian citizens fleeing the conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In addition to official schemes like this one in the UK, citizens have been taking to social media themselves to aid in the humanitarian effort.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Rooms for Ukrainians in the UK is one of the largest Facebook groups of its kind.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The man who only contacts single young women but hasn't actually got a profile himself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

All right, Matthew in the cube there, thank you very much. That's it for this special edition. Thank you for watching and goodbye.
